events.message: Add release not for version 1.0.1.1

This change affects the MaxGeneratedBlock, ExcessiveBlockSize & ExcessiveAcceptDepth qt text field widgets in the bitcoin unlimited settings dialog.

Before this change, the user could enter any junk text into these feilds and the dialog would accept that junk. When the user hit 'ok' then the settings would silently fail & the user would not be informed of the error or failure.

This change places QT integer validators on these text fields so that only a valid range of digits and integer value can be entered thus removing the 'silent fail' issue. This change also cleans up and simplifies the validation code for these fields. The changes are more consistant with the implementation of text fields elsewhere in the GUI (most of the other dialogs use QT Validators on textfields).

This change improves the user experience and removes the 'silent fail' that could happen when configuring these key fields.

Merge pull request #419 from AllanDoensen/multiMonFix

Fix for issues with startup and mutliple monitors on windows.

Ensure that we connect to at least a few XTHIN capable nodes.

In the past we relied on -addnode or -connect-thinblock to manually
configure connection to XTHIN capable nodes,  or to just rely on luck
in getting a connection.  Here we will actively seek out XTHIN nodes
and maintain at least 4 connections or the minimum number of outbound
connections whichever is less.

Differentiate the different types of Outbound nodes

During the period where we are disconnecting outbound nodes
in search of XTHIN supporting nodes we don't want to inadvertantly
disconnect outbound nodes that we've manually configured with -addnode
, -connect or -connect-thinblock.  So we use a separate fAutoOutbound flag
to differentiate from from the general fNetworkNode connections.

Use defined values for max number disconnects and min xthin nodes

MAX_DISCONNECTS = max number of disconnects allowed while searching for
xthin nodes.
MIN_XTHIN_NODES = min number of xthin nodes to connect.

Do not disconnect nodes during IBD

When searching for XTHIN capable nodes it is not necessary nor desireable
to disconect nodes during IBD for two reasons.  One is that XTHIN's can
not be downloaded anyway during IBD but more importantly, disconnecting
nodes can cause block download timeouts, therefore we don't want to
actively disconnect a node that may have already requested blocks to
download which can then unecessarily distrupt the IBD process.

When searching for XTHIN capable nodes, check whether IBD is complete.

During IBD we do not check and search for XTHIN capable nodes
however by the time IBD is completed all the outgoing connections are
already in use and the netcode is blocked waiting for a semaphore grant.
Therefore we need to use a try_wai() on the semaphore and then checked
every so often whether IBD is complete and if so then begin the search
for XTHIN nodes.

Make the MIN_XTHIN_NODES configurable.

using -min-xthin-nodes one can set the number of automatically
connected xthin nodes rather than only using the default of 4.
Add a CTweak() for min-xthin-nodes
fix formatting

Add exploit_tests.cpp

This new test is a catch all to test for any exploit type testing.

-Also move the p2p message exploit tests from thinblock_tests.cpp to
this test file.

-Make receive queues and ip addresses reuseable in exploit_tests.cpp

-Add tests for block consistency checking

Consistency checks for blocks are handled fully in checkblock_tests.cpp.

-Also cleaned up the formatting and added some comments to block handling
in main.cpp

-Add transaction consistency checks

These are fully covered in transaction_tests.cpp and
AcceptToMempool()

Add consistency check for VERSION, VERACK, BUVERSION AND BUVERACK

 If we havn't sent a BUVERSION message then we must not receive
 a BUVERACK message.

 Add check for proper handshake for VERSION and VERACK messages
 If we don't get a VERACK before sending the VERSION then ban.

Add tests for INV consistency checks

Move the fSuccessfullyConnected to when the VERACK is received.

 Because we now have a proper handoff from VERSION to VERACK we can
 move the setting of fSuccessfullyConnected = true to the when the
 VERACK is received.

Ban node if improper nVersion is received.

 Previously the node was only disconnected however a bad actor
 may still try to reconnect several times.

Disconnect peer if VERACK not received within the timeout period

  Also get more aggressive with peers that do not give us a VERSION
  message.  Ban them right away if we don't get a VERSION as the first
  message.

Updated logging information for ERROR messages

  Print out more information for the VERSION , VERACK, BUVERSION and
  BUVERACK error messages.

Only allow XPEDITEDBLK processing if IsChainNearlySyncd()

  and also when !fImporting and !fReindex

Do not process thinblock messages if peer is not thinblock capable

Make sure the thinblock will connect

  Check the BlockIndex and make sure the previous block in the thinblock
  header has an entry in the Blockindex.  If not then give a small
  misbehavior.

Ban peer if we receive an unrequested block

  We should never receive a full Block that was unrequested
  except from a whitelisted peer. This is a definite misbehavior.

Give small DOS20 if get_xblocktx can not find blocks on disk

  The requester already knows
  that we have the block on disk or they would not have gotten
  and inv or header to begin with so this is definite
  misbehavior.

Fix for potential deadlock

We have to do the lock on cs_main outside of the section
where we lock mempool.cs.

events.message: Add a release notes for BU 1.0.1.4

Merge pull request #470 from sickpig/doc/release-notes-1.0.1.4

[Doc] release notes 1.0.1.4

Show number of Orphans in the Information UI

It's a good idea to be able to see and also study the orphan
cache size as time goes by.  It would be good information to
have to start adjusting the size of the orphan cache timeout
which is currently tied to the transaction timeout.  In the future
we could decouple this so that orhpans could be purged more quickly
from the cache rather than waiting the standard 72 hours.  Having
the abililty to see the cache size in action will be helpful in
arriving at a good default value.

Erase orphans from previous block that was processed

Transactions often arrived after the current block is processed
and end up in the orphan cache.  When another block arrives we
can take the opportunity to erase those txns that are in the previous
block from the cach.

-Broaden the scope of erasing orphans from the cache

Using IsInitialBlockDownload() instead of IsChainNearlySyncd()
so as to remove orphans that have entered the pool when a node
is been shut down for a while and is catching up to the chain.

-Add 4 hour default timeout for txns in the orphan pool

Typically most orphans do not stay in the pool longer that a one minute
but are sometimes useful for as long as 90 minutes.  Beyond that time if
orphans are not used they will usually stay in the pool until the timeout
period and never be used.  Therefore by setting the timeout to 4 hours
rather than the previous 72 we can keep the orphan cache trimmed during
period of heavy mempool backlog and thereby also reduce the size of
the Xthinblock bloom filters.

-Update DOS_tests.cpp to use  the DEFAULT_ORPHANCACHE_EXPIRY

Reduce the default number of max orphans in the orphan pool.

With the latest updates to the way we handle the orphan cache we no
longer need such a big default cache.  It is rare that we get beyond
1000 now, even with severe backups in the mempool.  Generally we see
the cache now anywhere from 0 to 500 txns.
Delete orphans from the current block

Update UI banned list

-When a ban/unban happens internally (not through RPC) we need
to refresh the ban list in the UI.  Previous to this we
were only doing it if the ban was set through RPC only.

-Add 5 second Qtimer for automatically updating the banned list

When a ban comes to an end it will get deleted from the UI banned
list automatically rather than having to wait for another node
to be banned before the list would update.

-Keep use of SweepBanned() consistent for UI banned list

Dumping the banned list to disk every time the banned list is updated
is not necessary.  It gets dumped to disk every 15 mins and also when
the node shuts down.  Using sweepbanned is also consistent now with
the rest of the calls to bannning and unbanning of nodes.

-Several places in RPC calls for banning and unbanning
with redundant code.

-Make all calls to uiInterface.BannnedListChanged in src/net.cpp
This makes the code consistent for future use

-Add sweepbanned to listbanned

Make CNode::DumpBanList local to net.cpp

It only gets called in net.cpp so no need to have
it in net.h

Remove redunant SweepBanned from CNode::DumpBanList
Remove redundant call to SweepBanned() from updateTimer2
fix two small issues: side-effecting code in 2 asserts, and not releasing socket resources in an error condition

Merge #8613: LevelDB 1.19

Fix thinblock_tests.cpp

For some reason the deterministic bloom filtering is not entirely
reliable on the release branch and when running on Travis.  We see
an occasional bloom filter false positive when we shouldn't.

There is not big risk here, the bloom filter is only off by one
element but it is a bit of a mystery.  The deterministic behavior
of the bloom filter is governed by seed_insecure_rand().  I have
no idea why seed_insecure_rand() isn't always working as expected
but on other systems works fine, and also we don't see the issue
on the dev branch, at least not yet.

[ASAP for Release branch] Fix thinblock_tests.cpp

Clear ThinBlockTimer after the request is sent rather than when  received

Fix for issue #477

Clearing the timer after the request is sent rather than when the block
is received prevents the possiblity of downloading a block twice before
the RequestManager re-request timeout is exceeded.  Rely instead
only on the RequestManager to determine whether a block download timeout
has been exceeded.

Add documentation explaining the functioning of the thinblock timer.

Merge pull request #484 from ptschip/release_banned

[Backport for Release] fix auto updating of QT UI ban list

Merge pull request #511 from ptschip/release_482

[Release] backport of PR 482

Create expedited.cpp and expedited.h

Moved all expedited functions and definitions here.

Add CriticalSection cs_xpedited

This locks the following: XpeditedBlk, XpeditedBlkUp, and XpeditedTxn
Clean up code formatting for expedited in main.cpp

Cleanup HandleExpeditedBlock()

Also add cs_main lock for blockindex search.

Code cleanup for expedited.cpp

Clean up comments and remove commented out code.

Added note as to what cs_xpedited is protecting

protects 3 vectors:  xpeditedBlk, xpeditedBlkUp and xpeditedTxn

remove the using namspace std as it wasn't even necessary and also
we are moving away from using it.

use static variable declarations.

Replace the boost lexical casts

It's much simpler to just use an ostringstream here which doesn't carry
the problem of potential exceptions from lexical casting.

Use error messages instead of LogPrintf where applicable

Fix Cherry Picks

Don't process xpedited messages if thinblocks not enabled

  If the remote peer or your peer do not have thinblocks enabled
  then do not process expedited messages.

Add Thinblock message consistency checking for expedited transactions

Do not process an expedited block from a peer you have not specified as such

Do not allow urequested blocks/xthins/thinblocks unless from an expedited node

If a thinblock does not arrive in the timeout period then disconnect the node

This helps in two ways, to disconnect slow nodes but more importantly to clear
out the thinblock data being held in memory for that node.

Add locking for mapThinBlocksInFlight

Check mapThinBlocksInflight as well as mapBlocksInFlight before banning

There is a rare event that can happen when you have expedited processing
turned on an by chance you re-request a full Block.  If the
expedited block beats your re-request then mapBlocksInFlight will be
empty and you will end up banning a good node when the full Block
returns from the re-request.

This problem is a caused by mapBlocksInFlight not tracking by node id
as well as hash.

Lock mapThinBlocksInFlight before erasing elements, in parallel.cpp

Use xpeditedBlkUp to determine whether we have an expdited node or not

Move checking into HandleExpeditedBlock and HandleExpeditedRequest

Move  IsThinBlocksEnabled() IsThinBlockCapable() and IsExpeditedNode()
checks from main.cpp into the expedited functions.
solve block not requested race conditions, be more tolerant of slower nodes, and increase logging during qa node cache creation and during validateblocktemplate test

Take out the assigning of Misbehavior when un-requested block arrive

Assiging misbehavior here is causing issues with some tests such
as sendheaders.py that use mininode.  We'll have to think about
how best to proceed which doesn't break our tests.  So taking
this out for the time being.

Fix Cherry Pick
add validateblocktemplate.py to rpc-tests.py
Expedited blocks: only send after checking PoW

Remove validateblocktemplate.py

This is a 1.1 feature and got pulled over accidentally during a cherry
pick.
Remove redeclaration of CInv in main.cpp

[backport for Release] PR486 and PR502

Combine expedited block and xthin block handling

A common function that unifies the two message handlers to have a single codepath
for verification.  The only differences lie in determining new-ness of the block.
The prior expedited code path used to omit most of the validity checks.

backport of #541 into release (Check merkle root mutation in xthin/thinblock)

Whitelist test nodes to prevent banning in abandonconflict test

Issue: https://github.com/BitcoinUnlimited/BitcoinUnlimited/issues/537

Whitelisting them does not interfere with this test, and seems to lower the
probability of this test failing randomly. The remaining random hanging failure seems to have a different cause which remains to be investigated.

Prevent the mapThinBlocksInflight timer from tripping

In the event that we have received that thinblock and were
successful in reconstructing it we need to prevent the timer
from tripping before the block has finished processing. Set
the time = -1 and use it as a flag to prevent the node from
being disconnected if the time goes over limit.  We must
do this because we still need to maintain the map entry
to prevent us from downloading the block again.

Count bytes as we build a thinblock

And clear thinblock data and disconnect a node if the maximum bytes
permitted for concurrent thinblock re-construction has been exceeded.

If only one thinblock is currently being processed then it will
be the one selected for termination.

If more than one thinblock is in flight then the largest thinblock
will be terminated and the node disconnected.

Disconnecting the largest thinblock will automatically clear the
the thinblock data.

Add exploit tests for thinblock byte counting

Here we check if a thinblock bytes  has gone over the limite of
EB * 16.  We test both a single thinblock/xthiblock as well as
multiple blocks currently in flight. With mulitple blocks in
flight we have to ensure we disconnect the node with the largest
number of thinblock bytes in use.

Allow for a thinblock to continue processing

If we are processing a thinblock and we have gone over the global
limit, the largest thinblock processing will be terminated and the
node disconnected.  We have allow ourselves to continue in the event
that the largest is not *this* current node that is processing. So here
we return a bool to ClearLargestThinBlockAndDisconnect() and if false
then we can continue processing our thinblock.

Also added some tests to make sure we can both continue processing
and also terminate this thinblock if it also goes over the limit.

Use ClearThinBlockData() at the very beginning of thinblock processing

  Make sure we have a clean slate to work with and all counters
  are updated appropriately.

Update nLocalThinBlockBytes from within AddThinBlockBytes()

  This corrects a small accounting error in the byte counting as
  well as prevents further errors in the future.
calculate whether thinblock memory is too big before pushing anything, and disallow repeated tx in the thin blocks
clang-format, add log for too large block and apply the same logic to xthin and thin

Ensure we don't cause an integer underflow

Clear vRecv1 in thinblock tests

Use a bool return value for RequestBlock

This fixes a bug in the Request Manager when the first block source
can not be downloaded from because it is not a XTHIN peer.  Previously
we would have to wait for the download timeout to be exceeded before
trying again which could be as much as 30 seconds if rate limiting
was turned on.  Now as soon as another block source is available it
will be checked until we make our first request.

Merge pull request #605 from ptschip/release_rman

[Backport to Release PR588] request manager
Add test for handling of unconnecting headers

Use request manager for headers direct fetch

  When direct fetching is turned on we should add the block to
  the requeste manager request queue so that it can handle any
  potential re-requests if needed.

We can only handle one header per getdata at a time.

  You can not pass a vector of headers to the request manager and so
  only one getdata goes out per block hash.  Therefore we can not
  send batches of headers and expect a batch vGetData in return.

Dont prevent the request manager from adding more block sources

  When we receive headers we need to make sure we still do a
  requester.AskFor() even though we may already have the header.  The block
  may be in flight but may time out so we need to continue to add to the
  block sources.

Clean up requesting blocks for IBD

  Remove redundant code and only use requester.AskFor() for requesting
  blocks.

  Don't request blocks we already have on disk.  In AlreadyHave() we
  now check to see if we actually have the block and not just the
  header.  We do this so that we can still add block sources to the
  request manager even though the block may be in flight. This is
  important because if the block is in flight but times out we may
  end up with no available block sources when in fact there could
  have been one or more.

Check that the block headers are continous before proceeding

Do not accept block headers until we know that set of headers
is continous.  This prevents us from accepting headers and then
returning with an error before we are able to do a direct fetch.

Remove redundant code

Code no longer needed because we ask for all blocks and let
the request manager handle the requesting.
Fix indentation

Set uint256 to null

Update TODO

Add note as to why thinblocks must be off for sendheaders.py, which
is due to not having get_xthin support in mininode.

Test for special case when only a single non-continous header

It is possible that there will be just one non-continous header
and not two sent out of order.  We could receive the second header
but without the first present.

Turn Off PV during sendheaders.py testing

There are too many syncronization issues with PV and mininode
which causes occasional script failure.  Therefore we set
-parallel=0.  The problem is that the chain height is sometimes
still in the process of updating when we sync_with_ping and then
check the chain height which erroneously shows is behind.
Backport changes required for SENDHEADERS
Clang Format fixes
do not ban whitelisted peers

Default constructor should set priority

Otherwise reads of uninitialised memory in CRequestMangager::AskFor.
Also no reason why priority is a signed integer -  it seems unused currently; so make it
unsigned to have a lower-bound meaningful regardless of hardware integer size.

Clean up includes.

Once per day reset the number of nDisconnections allowed

Over time the MAX_DISCONNECTS will be hit as xthin nodes restart
or otherwise disconnect.  Therefore we need to reset the
nDisconnections to zero once per day to make sure we retain
the correct number of xthin node connections consistent with the
min-xthin-nodes config setting.

Reduce the MAX_DISCONNECTS

Now that we are replenishing the nDisconnects every day we
no longer need such a high value and can safely reduce this
to 200.
clang format fixes

Merge pull request #622 from kyuupichan/rm-1-release

[release] backport of #604

Merge pull request #607 from ptschip/release_sendheaders

[Backport to Release PR#455] SENDHEADERS

Merge pull request #613 from ptschip/release_minxthin

[Backport to Release PR#568] bug fix min-xthin-nodes

Keep track of the in memory orphan tx size

Start tracking this so we can limit the orphan cache size by
total bytes as well as by number of transactions.

Limit size of orphan pool by total bytes as well as transactions

Update code comments to reflect the new orphan pool handling.

Add unit tests for orphan pool max size allowed

Remove dead orphan pool code

For a long time we have not used this code for removing orphans by
peer and rely instead on number of orphans in the pool.
take out accidental printf left in code

Set nBytesOrphanPool to zero on startup

This happens during initialization when UnloadBlockIndex() is called
during startup.

Zero the nBytesOrphanPool if the orphan map has been cleared.

This is done before we add an orphantx in the event that the map
was cleared somewhere.
[Nit] Move "advertising address" log under "net"

Merge pull request #634 from ptschip/release_orphanbytes

[Backport to Release PR#580]  Limit orphan pool size by bytes and txns

Move bitnodes seeding to be after DNS seeding.

By removing the bitnodes seeding thread and moving the bitnodes
seeding to run after DNS seeding we prevent the problem on first
startup where binodes seeding finishes first and we end up with
100 entries from the leaderboard at the beginning of our address
list.  Whereas what we wanted is for the first entries to be coming
from our on BU seed list. And if no seeds could be found then and
only then get them from the bitnodes leader board.

Always add every block source during IBD

In the past we were only adding a block source if there was no
block currently in flight.  We want to always add more block
sources in the event that a block in flight is delayed. This way
we give the request manager the ability to re-request the block
from another source.

This is a possible bug fix for issue #575

Remove references to "staller"

  The block stalling code was taken out of BU and therefore
  the remaining references to it are no longer needed in the code.

Make FindNextBlocksToDownload a static function

Only remove block sources after block is stored to disk

  We only indicate to the request manager that the block was received
  after the block is accepted and stored to disk.  This way we prevent
  the same block being added as a block source after it has already
  been received, because before adding a block source we check if
  it is already on disk.  If it has been received but not stored then
  we could incurr an unnecessary re-request for a block that just
  arrived.

Remove unused variable "waitingfor"
Remove block stalling code

Reboot nolnet.

- New genesis block to force a new chain
- New network bytes so we don't interfere with old nolnet nodes
- After 20 minutes difficulty resets to 1 like on testnet3
- P2PKH addresses begin with B and P2SH with U
- BIP32 xprv and xpub prefixes are "Big " and "Blks".

Exports CreateGenesisBlock for use in an as yet uncommited script
by thezerg for adding an RPC call to create genesis blocks.
fix exception raised due to invalid type in CInv

Merge pull request #639 from ptschip/release_ibd

[Backport to Release PR629]  Always add block sources during IBD

Merge pull request #643 from kyuupichan/nolnet-release

[Release] Reboot nolnet.

Merge pull request #635 from ptschip/release_bitnodes

[Backport to Release PR627] Move bitnodes seeding to be after DNS seeding.

Increase the default min-xthin-nodes to 8

By increasing the min-xthin-nodes count from 4 to 8 we can increase
the connectedness of the XTHIN network significantly and further
protect against any attempt to partition the BU network of nodes by
some sort of sybil attack.  Furthermore we also increase the default
outbound nodes to 12 to ensure we also keep the current value of 4
for other types of nodes.  In short we increase the number of XTHIN
outbound nodes by 4 but keep other outbound nodes with the same count.

Cleanup thinblock.cpp

- system header files included first; remove unused one
- move exported utility function to util.cpp
- remove redundant local decls already in headers

Don't process unrequested xthins or xblocktx

  Only allow unrequested messages if from an expedited node.

Also remove redundant checking for an already received xthin. This
is now checked further upstream.

Add extra thin log message

  Indicate that the block was already received

Re-enable the thinblock re-request functionality

  Start Gathering the full tx hashes and keep track of missing
  txns in setHashesToRequest.

  Temporarily remove code for finding the repeating sequences of
  hashes in a possibe attack block.

use setHashesToRequest.size() to determine whether to start building
the thinblock.

  Make appropriate re-requests if any hashes or txns are still missing.

Add mapMissingTx to CNode
  We'll need to keep this data if we do a  re-requests.

revert to boost foreach and make this easier to backport

Begin xblocktx refactoring

  update the xThinBlockHashes with the full hashes of the txns
  supplied in the xblocktx.

Reconstruct the block after we have all the tx hashes.

Check for any repeating transaction id sequences

  This was previously being done when we first received the xthin
  however we did not necessarily have all the hashes at that point.

  Also, by putting the check in ReconstructBlock() we ensure that
  every block reconstruction is checked for repeating sequences
  regardless of whether it is from an xthinblock and thinblock or
  a reconstruction from an xblocktx.

Don't process xblocktx or thinblocks if we already have the block

  If expedited nodes are sending us xthins or if we have re-requested
  them the responses can be beaten by other incoming xthins.  We don't
  want to process them twice if we already have the block on disk.

Clear out thindata after every block is processed

  Whether we had a thinblockinflight or not we still need
  to clear out the thindata for this peer in the event that we
  have either an expedited block or an attack block
  from an unrequested peer.

Tidy up logging for thinblocks

  Add more clarity to logging regarding xthinblock or thinblock.

Remove redundant erase from orphan cache after block processing

  We erase orphans now after a block has finished processing when a PV
  thread completes.

Add an expedited block to mapThinBlocksInFlight

  When an expedited block arrives we must track it as a thinblock
  in flight so that we don't end up requesting a thinblock from the
  same expedited node.  For example, this could happen if the expedited
  block re-requested for additional transactions and during that re-request
  we may receive and INV or header which results in a request
  for an additional xthin.

Cleanup copy paste code with AddThinBlockInFlight()

Make sure we cleanup thinblock data if we return early

  Make consistent use of cleanup functions when returning
  after and error or because we already have the block.

Use GetLogName() rather than node id in thinblock.cpp

  Standardize all log messages in thinblock.cpp to use GetLogName()
  rather than using node id.

Erase thindata before thinblock in flight.

  This is likely more of an issue on regtest where we could erase
  the thinblock in flight and end up requesting another thinblock
  before or at the same time the thindata was erased.

Do not assingn misbehavior if the block can not be loaded from disk

  This is not really a peer misbehavior, it is our own problem and
  furthermore in the stop above we assing misbehavior for a block
  request which does not exist in the block index.

  Also, assigning misbehavior for a block that is not yet on disk
  can happen with expedited nodes.  We do not want to end up banning
  expedited nodes for blocks that have not yet been reconstructed.

  TODO: the problem of requesting blocks not yet on disk is really
  a current limitation of the request manager.  The request manager
  should really wait for the arrival of either an INV or a HEADER
  to indicate that the peer we are needing to request an xblocktx
  does in fact have the block on disk.

Make sure to LOCK cs_main before checking AlreadyHave().

  We could just lock cs_main at the beginning of AlreadyHave() but
  because it gets called so frequently (with cs_main is already locked)
  and these two instances we are modifying are rarely called, it makes sense
  to only lock cs_main ourselves when/if we need it.

Use a struct to track thinblocksinflight information

Previously we were only tracking the time the thinblock was requested
but we may want to add more tracking information in the future and
also for the time being at fReceived to indicate that the thinblock
was fully reconstructed and is ready to be processed as a block.

Disregard whether this node is thinblock capable or not

In determining whether this node should be disconnected for having
gone beyond it's timeout for downloading a thinblock we should not
care that this is a thinblock capable node or not.  If it's an
attack node they may have somehow gotten an entry into the
thinblocksinflight map and therefore we should make the check
regardless of the node serices they are advertising.
Update thinblock_tests.cpp to reflect the new mapThinBlocksInFlight
cherry-pick fix

Relax banning for VERSION and VERACK type messages

There is little risk in recieving duplicates or unrequested messages
of this type so disconnecting can cause less problems if a valid node
for instance didn't perform that handshake correctly.  This way
they can just may another attempt.

Do not assign Misbehavior if unconnecting headers are received

This is typcially not a misbehavior and can and does happen on
mainnet when two blocks are mined by different miners but very
close in time to one another.  Some nodes will receive these
headers out of order and while on mainnet giving a small misbehavior
is not a big issue for this rare event it has caused some problems
on the nolnet test environment.

The next step will be to add the ability to cache these un-connecting
headers until such time as the needed header arrives and both can
then be properly connected.
Remove comments that are no longer valid
Add strCommand to log message if VERSION not received first.
fix formatting
add missing constructor for CThinBlockInFlight()

Merge pull request #655 from ptschip/release_minxthin

[Backport to release of PR641] Increase the default min-xthin-nodes to 8

Merge pull request #656 from ptschip/release_xthin

[Backport to Relase PR 603] re-enable xthins

Fix --enable-debug on OSX

Requires unsigned long overloads as that is size_t on OSX.
However on some platforms that conflicts with the uint64_t overloads.
Resolve by removing the typedef overloads and having for both unsigned long
and unsigned long long.

Closes #663

Merge pull request #664 from kyuupichan/univalue-release

[Backport to release of #624] Fix --enable-debug on OSX

Remove 4 hour ban if initial headers not received

This ban is problematic when mining larger blocks and also
due to the single threaded message processing in the release
branch.  When very large blocks are being processed and a new
peer is trying to connect at the same time then a delay can
happen which exceeds the header download timeout. As a result
we can ban a node that is a good node.  By disconecting instead
the peer can try to re-connect again later.

Make sure we receive recent headers when doing initial handshake

When we request the intial headers from a peer during the time
we make connection with the peer make sure the headers returned
are recent ones.  An attacker could just send us any old valid
header so we need to ensure that we receive headers that are at
or greater than our block height at the time of requesting.

Merge pull request #670 from ptschip/release_header

[Backport to Release PR# 666] Relax ban for initial headers

Renable the check IsInitialBlockDownload() for txns during IBD

We want to ensure we don't unnecessarily download txns during IBD.
This will be more important as txn rates rise further.

Merge pull request #672 from ptschip/release_txns3

[backport to Release] Renable the check IsInitialBlockDownload() for txns during IBD

Changed http:// to https:// on one link

Changed http:// to https:// on one link in README.md

Do not check scripts unless blocks are less than 30 days old

Thanks to Tom Zander and Tom Harding.  This PR is based on their
commits for their respective projcts.

We still allow one to force the checking of scripts by the use
of fCheckpointsEnabled however in general we only will check the
signatures for the last 30 days of blocks. All other block checks
are still performed for all blocks.
fix format

Do not continue if the header will not connect

When receiving and expedited or xthin make sure that there
is a previous block header to connect with.

Remove DOS from unconnecting thinblock

This is not necessarily a misbehavior and can be treated like
an out of order header.

Merge pull request #686 from ptschip/release_headers

[Backport to Release PR#685] Do not continue if header will not connect

Merge pull request #676 from sandakersmann/patch-1

Changed http:// to https:// on one link

Merge pull request #680 from ptschip/release_ibd

[Backport to Release PR#192] Do not check scripts unless blocks are less than 30 days old

Also check pindexBestHeader when determining fScriptChecks

Since we can be reasonable sure we have all the headers when we
do IBD or receive new blocks then we can also check if we are
within approx 30 days of the chain tip by block height.  We still
keep the check that timeBarrier is also within 30 days but by
having both checks it makes it more difficult to attack in some
way.

Merge pull request #690 from ptschip/release_checkpoints

[Backport to Release] Also check pindexBestHeader when determining fScriptChecks
match against altnames and the CN (common name) so that different spam and hosting solutions work.  Fix the short read error (fix provided by @bitcartel).
reformat bitnodes files

Handle headers that won't connect right away.

At times we can receive out of order headers.  If we do we store
the unconnecting header in a cache and check if it will connect
each time a new header arrives.

Out of order headers should typically
exist for only a few seconds at most, therefore if the unconnecting
header is in cache for more than 2 minutes we will delete it.

There is also the possiblity of an attack to prevent node sync from
happening during the intial download of headers.  If we get out of
order headers and we are far from today then we disconnect the peer
so that we can start downloading initial headers from another peer.
Add more tests for unconnecting headers in sendheaders.py
Revert to BOOST_FOREACH instead of c++11 for loop

[Backport to Release PR#650] Handle uncontinuous headers
